channel.title: Netty
channel.description:
Hmm yes. I don't see why moparclassic not running with NETTY? The latency is so freaky slow.
Could someone explain why it has not been implemented in first place. I have always wondered why too use MINA instead of NETTY anyway.

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

With regard to multi-threading, what xEnt said is entirely correct. Trying to hack a single-threaded application to use multiple threads will almost always end bad, you instead need to write it with an eye for concurrency from the start.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Look at those specs. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Dell_PowerEdge_Servers

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

The original RSC wouldn’t have been multithreaded because, back in those days, Java’s memory model did a very poor job at catering for concurrency.
Pretty sure volatile didn’t work properly until version 5, and I imagine any concurrency API back then was bug-prone (which is why so much stuff is deprecated in the java API today).

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @nacional nacional
item.description:
@nacional wrote:

ask him, on his tweeter he seems to answer questions

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

It’s obvious netty is “better” because it was created by the same guy, he took what he learned from mina and implemented it with netty. The performance boost is very minimal because CFF is correct, it relates the the server architecture.

I will put all my money to the fact that the original version of runescape is not multi-threaded when concerning player updating.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

what CFF said.

StorkPK as far as i remember, is dual threaded and not dynamic, which isn’t that hard, however when you add the ability to do x amount of threads you need to do things differently. Writing a server from the ground up isn’t that hard to do with multi threading, but turning the current RSCD sources to having dynamic threading is a different story, not only do you need to change code in hundreds of areas, you need to find them as you play.

At projectrsc, someone else put the multi threading in, and whilst it might have worked well with 1 person online, it was a different story with lots of others, andi wasn’t going to run around patching up each part of code when the server went live, as it would have felt like a disgustingly unfinished server with bugs left right and center.

the performance gain wasn’t worth the amount of time, or crashes/bugs the server would face, not to mention people want the server out now, not next year.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:16, topic:458604"][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=561514.msg4100387#msg4100387 date=1347391216]

[quote author=-Nothing link=topic=561514.msg4100339#msg4100339 date=1347384454]

Why the hell did you go back to singlethreaded?
[/quote]Because it’s a massive undertaking, and would be easier to start from scratch…

If you don’t, you’ll constantly have to fix the hardest kinds of bugs.

Also, you’re not going to gain that much perceived speed.

StorkPK was multithreaded, of course there was many bugs due to concurrency, but I fixed them all and there was only 1 major bug left with the server, which had to do with the Lothy’s region system, I never bothered to fix it as I lost interest pretty fast after my birthday, due to the amount of disrespect from the community for being in-active for 3 days…
[/quote]I highly doubt it… There was probably 1 major bug left that was happening all the time…

If there was I wasn’t aware of it.[/quote]That’s exactly my point… Concurrency bugs are a royal pain in the ass to find, especially seeing they can be very rare.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

ill set things straight,

there were several branches of prsc with multi threading, i didn’t do anything in them and i have no clue if some of it was taken from Apollo. I do know the current version of prsc doesn’t use multi threading and does use netty and as CFF said, there is no reason netty would make the server feel lower latency than mina, the reason prsc feels lower latency is because a lot more data is sent instantly to the client instead of waiting for the server loop.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:8, topic:458604"][quote author=KO9 link=topic=561514.msg4099345#msg4099345 date=1347246001]

why would you use netty over mina? why would you use netty over java nio?

Due to complexity and relatively poor performance. Netty is consistently faster & has faster development cycle.
Well in all google links about netty vs mina I look into, clearly states Netty has the best performance compared to MINA.

[/quote]It’s not a trivial conversion due to the tight coupling throughout the entire application.

Also, the latency isn’t due to MINA, it’s just the way the server is designed. Sure, Netty could improve it, but it’s not the major factor.

ProjectRSC switched from mina to netty and saw HUGE benefits with regards to latency. No other changes were made to cause this other than mina->netty.

ProjectRSC is multithreaded aswell. I have an outdated src of it which btw shows clearly that the devs have ripped lots from the RS2 server Apollo.[/quote]I’m going to assume it’s not just ripped, but completely butchered as well… You can’t really just rip things from Apollo and apply them nicely to RSCD, everything is going to be a giant mess.

Though, I sincerely hope it’s nowhere near as bad as RSCA was.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty
item.dc:creator: @vortex vortex
item.description:
@vortex wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:8, topic:458604"][quote author=KO9 link=topic=561514.msg4099345#msg4099345 date=1347246001]

why would you use netty over mina? why would you use netty over java nio?

Due to complexity and relatively poor performance. Netty is consistently faster & has faster development cycle.
Well in all google links about netty vs mina I look into, clearly states Netty has the best performance compared to MINA.

[/quote]It’s not a trivial conversion due to the tight coupling throughout the entire application.

Also, the latency isn’t due to MINA, it’s just the way the server is designed. Sure, Netty could improve it, but it’s not the major factor.

ProjectRSC switched from mina to netty and saw HUGE benefits with regards to latency. No other changes were made to cause this other than mina->netty.

ProjectRSC is multithreaded aswell. I have an outdated src of it which btw shows clearly that the devs have ripped lots from the RS2 server Apollo.[/quote]Which is not a bad thing

Read full topic
